author: LAPhill
content:
Shout out to @Tim O’Sullivan for not only finally solving my hum issues, but dialing in the workflow in my room to a whole other level. He wired up all my pedals, synths, and preamps to a couple of patch bays so I can throw signal all around the room in any order (complete with right-angle cables so I can use them with the desk doors closed). He also built MIDI lines to send clock from my DAW to the pedals and we upgraded the room to Mio MIDI-over-Ethernet units. Several other creature comforts that allow me to think less, like routing a headphone connection underneath the right side of my desk instead of the left where my interface is, adding a second one by the piano, and ready-to-go cables for guitars, synths and microphones already plugged in where they need to be.

I'm going to run out of reasons not to call this studio "done" soon.

author: P.K. Stephan
content:
Hey guys! I am new to the community and happy to have finally taken the jump into the discord after being an avid listener since the beginning.

Just finished building my studio about half a year ago. I run a hybrid setup where everything is always connected and ready to go. All recording paths are accessed via an XLR patch-bay. Mixbus/Mastering gear is controlled by a Dangerous Liaison. Conversion is done via MADI and AES/EBU. Headphone CUE’s are analog and via AVB. I like having everything connected and mic’ed up because I notice that I only use the stuff that I can access quickly while producing/mixing. I went through a lot of trial and error building and working in this studio (been in this location for 1.5 years) so if anyone needs any input I would be happy to help!

author: cian riordan

author: peterlabberton
content: Babysitting/demoing an EQ and compressor that my dear friend Raphael Peterson designed and built (@oaklandmatt Raphael of Dizzy Balloon!). Bottom two are the same stereo compressor: diode bridge with some special other thing going on in the circuit that I can’t remember at the moment. Attack and release work kind of like the UnFairchild—the “speed” control sets the general range, and then you can fine tune. Top is a Pultec inspired tube EQ with a unique mid band: instead of selecting the frequency and Q, you select the bottom range of the band and the top range of the band with the “corner” controls. You can also turn it into a low or high shelf with the “curve” control. It can do really bold moves; I think he said it can boost up to 20dB, at least on certain bands, and just playing around it can do a lot. I’ve only just given them a rough run through but they are so far very very cool! (Plus I love the hand written controls.)

author: peterlabberton
content:
So far I’m using the S1 to:

a) have hands on control when mixing drums, as I’ve got a handful of parallel compression and distortion auxes. I’ve made it work with a keyboard and mouse, but being able to have one hand on an audio track fader and the other on the return of a parallel effect is great.

b) setup VCAs for my whole mix and, once I’ve got things in a good spot, close all the pro tools windows so I’m more focused on just listening, and play the mix back and write automation.

These are both just things I’ve missed about working on a console, and I’m glad to be able to reincorporate them into my workflow.

And to put the EQ on, I sent my main PT output to a virtual output, and have the EQ on there in Console, assigned to the monitors.

author: LAPhill
content: Something that's worked pretty well for me is to not worry about fret noise, squeaks, finger buzz, etc., until it pulls you out of the song. As in, don't go surgically cleaning up your tracks until you hear them in context and see if something is poking out in a bad way. Humanity is almost always a good thing in a record and removing all those little imperceptible things can make a performance feel lifeless. And if that's what you want, maybe just use samples?

author: popaganda.
content: Can I interject and steer the convo in a direction that might help some of the lurkers? I tried to throw ns10s into the mix a few years ago and they really confused me. But I can't deny that my heros made great shit on them. There seem to be 2 common denominators I've seen for ns10 people. Either you came up in big studios and they were always there as a reliable reference and you learned them over time. In this context part of the sound of the ns10 is actually the desk reflection. Or you learned from a mentor who worked on them and picked up all the voodoo tricks that helped make them translate. Anybody who had a real mentor likely understands ns10s because they were ubiquitous to genX and before. I'm trying to understand if there's any use to a 25 year old now who's never been in a big studio or had a mentor and wants to do good work. I was the first to discourage someone from getting them yesterday in monitoring. Was my take wrong?

author: Preston Lull
content:
Make sure to find a good luthier and get it set up well! Get it intonated (saddles, and nut height so you’re not pulling the strings out of tune in the first positions) and get the neck adjusted and action set. 
get it feeling GOOD to play.
#1 reason people don’t continue with guitar is that the setup on their guitar is wonky and they never even knew, they thought it was just hard to play

author: Eric Martin
content:
I’ve used it on vocals all the time.

It has the harmonic Neve character that you’d expect. The 1176 is a nice thing to have right there in the same box, but I don’t love that there isn’t a separate output for the pre and input for the comp, it makes dialing in the amount of harmonic character and compression interdependent.

The overall output control is noisy if the dual isn’t set perfectly in this one spot, which is also annoying, I’m saving to upgrade to a pair of Great Rivers and another distressor instead of the 1173.

author: peterlabberton
content: I think it’s great! I’m by nature hesitant to make unequivocal recommendations unless I’ve really had a chance to do real side by side comparisons, and in truth I don’t do *tons* of vocals here. Have had it for maybe a year and a half, tracked vocals with maybe 3-5 singers with it. I like it because it’s very flexible without leaning on any DSP wizardry, which was a selling point when I was shopping around for a quality mic that could cover a lot of bases. Really love it as a center drum overhead. Have used it in the B mode on a dimed bass cab and it did great. Would love to put it up to a couple classics and have a good singer shoot them all out to feel like have a better sense of it, but my metric in this room and situation is: does it do the job? And so far 9/10 it does.

author: ALXCPH
content:
The Way i like to balance these things is to devide my time. When i have more work i focus on that and forget everything i know about perfect setups and the correct Way to do stuff and try to work from instinct. When i have less work thats when i like to dig and explore/optimise. 

I def Think the two mindsets can coexist as long as one is conscious about it. 
I love optimising because it makes the creative/work time much easier and instinctual because it helps me trust those instincts. But I would never let doubts stop me doing work and getting over some finish line.

author: GaspardMurph
content:
I thought I’d share my setup here ! I love my space here but I am starting to feel like I’ve hoarded myself into a corner. Too much stuff accumulated that I don’t need / use.
Here is my plan to make more room, if anyone has an opinion, please shoot 🙂
- condense all the rack gear into one of the rack cabinets, there a ton of stuff that is just in there and not being used (nor is it patched in)
- Rhodes is going to my house, I think it will get more use as a practice / songwriting tool in my home.
- Mellotron goes where Rhodes was, so I can store my tape echoes on the drawer cabinet
- Smaller desk: I need to find the right one or have one built but I really only need my prophet, mouse and keyboard.
- Would also be a good opportunity to improve speaker placement

The room is smaller than it looks in the pictures, it’s 161 sq feet. About 14.9’ long, 11.9’ wide and 7.6’ high. It’s a floating room design and there is acoustic treatment behind the fabric walls (no idea what though)

author: Brian Reynolds
content: I knew you were, about 20 seconds after sending the message I realized what was going on with me. And needed to step away before I could communicate clearly. A wise man once said hold the things loosely, it's the people that matter. What was upsetting me was, that the collective concern was with safety and security of the cloud and the gear. And not with the human and their mindset who was going to work on an elevated surface or ladder. As someone whose father fall from a ladder. Altered my life for the better part of a decade. And will alter every step my father takes forever. The most important thing once elevated surfaces, tools, and suspended weight get involved. Is that the people come down alright. Clouds can be remade. Gear can be rebought. Money can hear remade. But when a human body breaks. It never goes back together the same way. I'm sensitive around this topic.

content: Not sure what you mean?  ...   the amount of signal is proportional to the decibel level of the source more than the preamp gain setting, and full orchestra is a loud beast.  Each channel is set so that FFF dynamics (barely) don't clip the preamp and the mix at unity and loud full orchestra is kissing into a brickwall limiter at -1db.  It might push the loudest peaks at 3-6db in reduction. But the RMS is all over the place. Final mix probably close to -20 LUFS program average.

author: peterlabberton
content:
My future setup. Will of course need to adapt as I get in the room and listen, but I'm excited *and* need to minimize downtime between studios, so I'm mapping stuff out as best I can so I can hit the ground running.

I'm thinking I'll build some fiberglass/rockwool panels on stands (the four panels freestanding by the mix position) and mimic some of the idea behind the attack wall: kill reflections closer to the listening position rather than at the walls. This way I can keep the fireplace and windows from being covered up, and have some gobos to move around when needed for tracking. The small desk to the left of the mix position will be a rack for gear, the large rectangular thingy in the upper right will be an upright piano. I'll pack in some DIY tube traps around the monitors, and hang two 4'x2' panels I already own over the mix position. I'll also put two slightly smaller panels over the drums, and two more on the wall behind the drums. The french doors and the sliding doors to the closet behind the couch will have heavy curtains.

author: cian riordan
content:
So here’s the roundup on my dumb drum thing. This is a scrappy little experiment on my part to see if I can get a convincing drum sound in my little drum room. Before starting this, I had the idea in my mind that if a room is good for mixing, it must be good for recording! *Insert Game Show Buzzer* I ran into many of the things I didn’t like about the Barefoot Studio B Live room — and those things were exaggerated by a factor of 10. First of all, my room is very dead by design. It treats me great in mixing, but made for a real challenge when trying to get *some* sort of drum personality. I was also working with a pretty shitty old premier kit that hadn’t seen the light of day in half a decade. Shitty cymbals, very quickly tuned heads — I wasn’t setting myself up for success… but whatever.

The setup was a little ridiculous (minus a few utilitarian pieces):
Kick: Beta 52 -> Scully 280
Snare: SM57 -> Scully 280
OH Mono: Coles 4038 -> Ampex 351 -> 1176 (not compressing, just to trim gain before ‘tools)
OH L/R: U67s -> UTA pre (thanks Matt!)
Kick Room: U47 -> UTA Pre (again…)

This is where I ended up, without mixing, and with some quick playing and utility EQ/balancing. No compression except a limiter to bring up the level. While the actual drums themselves don’t sound amazing, I really struggled with getting any sort of energy out of the drums… it all just got sucked out. 

Here are the results if you care (don’t judge my shitty playing)

I think if it do this again I would:
1) Have a better sounding kit. Turns out, shit in.. shit out. I knew this. We all know this. But here I am.
2) Maybe put some sheets of plywood around to create some surface in the room. Just give it some life.
3) Not use the Scully. It’s so hard to get them to not sound distorty… I just don’t have enough pres on hand to have clean path for everything. Mix studio living.

So it goes…

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Excited to check this...been building something similar. Right now it will take in all my project info, use that to create the file structure, upsample my originals using RX, create an entry in my Google Sheet project tracking app, create an invoice for the project with all the naming/pricing, then create, move the files into, and prep/save the Wavelab session for me.

It also copies all the project info into Wavelab and there is another script that names all the tracks/sets up the render too. All from that one data entry point in the beginning (mine is currently just an Applescript since it's still being worked on).

You gave me the initial idea, Nathan Dantzler at the Hit Lab gave me the idea to tie it all into the business backend.

Thank you so much, it's actually unbelievable how efficient it is, and there is only one possible point of failure for naming/QC which is easy to check.

author: jmlongmusic
content:
Hey everyone! I’m new to the community - really enjoying it so far. This will be a long post asking for some studio build advice — I hope that’s ok. Please just let me know if there’s a better thread for this sort of thing. 

I’d be extremely grateful for any feedback! Here’s some info: 

- I am currently moving my home studio to this basement space that is about 400 SQ feet. Concrete floor and walls except for the front wall shown in this picture - that is drywall as it separates the rest of the basement. 

- The ceiling joists are exposed and are about 7.5” deep. 

- My primary function for this room will be mixing, but I will also be doing smaller overdubs like piano and vocals. 

Currently, after painting the walls and floor, my plan is as follows: 
- Stuff the ceiling joists with insulation — probably Safe N Sound… thoughts on that choice? 

- Cover the joists with fabric from Gilford of Maine. 

- Figure out how to drill into concrete 😂 Then put panels everywhere. Most of my panels are about 4” thick and are comprised of the safe n sound insulation. 
- Put some big rugs down but also leave a bit of the concrete exposed if possible cuz I like the look. Haha 

- My monitoring set up is NS10M’s (don’t laugh) with an Avantone CLA-100 amp and a PreSonus T10 sub. I’ve got an Apollo 8 Duo and Apollo Twin X Quad. 

That concludes my plan so far. Am I on the right track? 😳 

I really appreciate any feedback you’re willing to give. 🙏

author: itMIGHTbeNICK
content:
This is my humble home setup in the corner of my bedroom. There’s nothing glamorous here. While I’m still building out the room downstairs and things have been at a hault due to some financial difficulties I won’t get into. I’m doing most of my work right here these days if I can’t get studio time at my buddys space. I’m incredibly proud of the mixes and masters I’ve been able to do in this little corner. I set up some gobos and tube traps I have in the closet when I’m getting deep into the mix and it’s all been working out as best as it can for the situation at hand.
NS10’s have the cap mod. 

When I need to track my guitar amps I completely isolate them with long cables and treatment directly in my closet or I will close off the bathroom and treat them in there as well as capture the natural reflection in our bathroom. My wife and kids are so incredibly sensitive and generous to me during this time to even let me still be able to work and make this happen while the studio build is on hold and we’re having to make things work.

So it goes 1. Mic lines /

10. Direct outs
11.interface IN 
12 blank
13 blank 
14. Console center section
15. Aux sends

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Keep in mind speakers can get damaged even if you don't see it. I shouldn't mention any specifics but I once had a speaker shipped with pretty decent packaging (double boxed, foam etc) which UPS managed to drop so hard the woofer's motor tore entirely off. It wasn't even some cheap stamped frame. High end pretty heavy duty (metal) frame. Yours might not get damaged to that extreme but could get cracked and have problems later on. Shipping speakers that are large enough to have real weight to them but not heavy enough that you need a pallet is risky business. Almost guaranteed to get tossed off a truck

author: Will Pragnell
content: How do you like the Ferrofish A32? I've been eying up the A32 pro. Big part of my use case would be for recording eurorack... do you happen to use those together, and is so, how does the A32 cope with hot eurorack levels?

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
I can't say enough good things about A32 tbh.  The converters are VERY good with no discernable difference between A32 and the RME UFX+  ...  but it's my mixer bridge more than modular.  The modular routes to an old Apogee, and can then MADI into the mixer (if you wanted to get real tweaky with EQ or use compressors).  

As far as levels go...    the A32 does something I had no experienced with other converters, and I love it.  You can adjust the sensitivy of the analog input...  Here's a better explanation from the manual

> The analog inputs of the A32 DANTE can each be set to different
> sensitivities. You can choose between three reference levels: +4dBu,
> +13dBu and +20dBu. Using the DSP, you can additionally set the
> reference levels from -8dBu to +20dBu in 1 dB steps. The DSP always
> calculates the optimum configuration. For example, if you set +12dBu,
> the analog reference will be set to +13dBu and the signal will be
> attenuated by 1dB.

That would work magic with eurorack levels.  I use it sometimes so that I can overdrive the Trident and keep the channel direct outputs under the limiter's clipping stage. Helps when you want to be abusive in analgo but not worry about converters clipping.

As i've gotten more into coffee the past year or so, it's been interesting seeing how the "sum of parts" concept applies to other things, especially music cus that's what we do. Grind size, time of brew, temperature of water, brew method, etc. Used to not buy into it, but they certainly affect the outcome. Mic, placement, preamp, quality of the source, etc. are all important too!

author: Brian Reynolds
content: Unless Im seeing this incorrectly.  It doesnt look like the door is square or level. So the weatherstipping and or getting to door to close flush, is always going to be a challenge.  Cedar shims and a gap area should of been used to level off the door before securing it. Nothing is ever perfectly square, the door, the wood, the ground. So you need allowances with doors. Youll never notice the corner of a wall meeting slighlty out of plum. But a door always shows it. You can see how the top of the door isn't running level from right to left with the image your finger is pointing at the hole. #2 You can add any expanding insulation foam, or clear caulk to fill those small slots. Once covered in trim though. I doubt much sound if any is going to make through the trim and through those small holes
